Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2011 03:24PM - edited Dec 15, 2011 05:02PM by apple first of all .. possible nausea, eat 30 minutes after a small meal, take pills, then eat a bit more in about 10 minutes.. i usually favor bland food like cheerios nuts or bananas. Moisterize moisterize etc. X 10.  I use very thick creams like aquaphor and put inspector gloves on my hands and socks on my feet.  you can order the gloves on the net, about 8 dollars a dozen.. They can be washed every day. At the beginning hand and foot issues shouldn't surface but probably will later on. I play professionally as an organist/pianist and have maintained my hands over 13 cycles.  they are a bit stiffened as the skin tightens and swells a bit.  I soak my feet about 2 X a month and rub off all the accumulating dead skin.. and then moisterize times 10. I've needed lots of rest.. at least an extra hour day, and a daily nap has been a godsend for me.  I take fish oil for joint aches and a pain med.. hydrocodone.  I try to take as little as possible but find that days 10 to 14 a bit challenging and now am up to the maximum dosage.  My onc. offered my stronger meds but i declined.. i'll save them for later. i try to eat extra protein.. my appetite has been fairly low and food just doesn't taste all that good.  not bad, just not good.  if i were to skip a meal, i wouldn't notice.  AFter my last few days i have to indulge in a bit of binge and stock back up.  My weight has been stable. about the gloves.. i like the nylon because they don't shrink and stay white when you wash them.. (in the laundry with hot water and bleach.. the cotton work for a while, and then need to be thrown away.  I use silk gloves when i play the piano.... kind of pricey tho at 8 bucks a pair and have to be hand washed. http://www.grainger.com/Grainger/inspection-gloves/hand-protection/safety/ecatalog/N-b1m

Posts.Content: apple wrote: My friend drives me around - selflessly driving me to 5 stores in one day.. and she cleans my house (she's not the best housecleanier) - altho things sure look fantastic by the time she leaves and there is an unusual tension about paying your friend but it's a win/win. So i asked my kids to preclean -  my daughter chose my office to preclean.. i have a sewing machine, a church organ and my office desk.  Everyone uses my office because it has the best computer. So the office looks marvelous... all dusted and shine up.    She stacked the 'to kill a mockingbird' essay papers, the Eagle Scout project papers, all my music that i print out and must be sorted weekly neatly in a stack on the organ bench along with all the cards I've been sent..   largest to smallest so the stack looks nice.  So now i have a system.. I've made a list (it's about a mile long, of all the gals I  want (i said want) to thank.. and all i have.   it will be easy.  Grateful for all the showers in Kansas.. We sure need the rain around here.  I planted so many things and they really need to soak.. All the cards are making me much more hopeful that I'll accomplish quite a few more things.. and my kids are absolutely blown away that I've gotten so many.. I don't cater much to the finesse of manners and thank you cards, but have always responded to gifts.. i am my mother's daughter.   I might have to remove yet another boob, if my brain can stand it.. that will bum my husband out altho i have no idea why he likes the remaining one at the moment.  I should have let him nurse when he asked. it's kind of a bummer to acknowledge that i need housecleaning help.  i already yell at my kids enough.. they have plenty of work to do.  i don't want to rob them or their childhood by making them slave away or instilling good work habits or ethics. (they do have daily chores and help me on fun projects)  I still am making money because son # 2 drives me to my jobs for which i pay him a percentage.  getting a paycheck is such a nice thing.  My husband lets me partially own his company for being the office.. it's not that there is any cash in that transaction. well one shouldn't talk about money in polite company. peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 04:11AM - edited Jan 9, 2012 04:13AM by apple we stumbled upon our current property a couple years ago (Feb.).. there was a realtor's sign and it said 'acreage'.  We called the number, the realtor was inside,  we went into look at it and made an offer on our way out of the driveway.  It was an incredible find.. the price had been lowered by 50% the two years it was on the market.. no one had the ability or desire to tackle such a HUGE mess, but my husband made it into a beautiful home and base for his small remodeling company.  For the price of a bungalow we bought 2+ acres and the shell of a large house... good, solid shell, tho with some brilliant, functional, design details. the house is actually huge.. a series of additions had been haphazardly added onto the original farm house.. it is right smack dab in the middle of the city, but has a septic tank.    you can see a few of the before pics here.  we are fortunate and happy. http://stevermercompanybuildingblog.blogspot.com/

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 08:29PM - edited Feb 19, 2012 08:30PM by apple our search function is EXCELLENT.. in the upper left hand task bar there is a 'search' option.. you just type in the words and voila. swishing with baking soda, nasal irrigation to keep the passages clear, and lots and lots of water help.  There is a product (group of products in the dental section of the pharmacy called Biotin).. they help.  I make a spray of water, lemon juice (sounds counter productive, but in encourages saliva production, mint and glycerine.. (yes, you can eat it.. it's in candy and I find it at my Mexican store or the pharmacy)  that helps me at nite.  Many of our meds cause mouth sores. Actively keeping them moisterized and clean helps a lot and can keep them at bay. brushing gently with baking soda is awesome and not painful. please post further if you can't find the search function.. it is next to 'community rules, under log in, and log out... upper left task bar. There also is a subforum called sorry for the different fonts.. i guess i am not the most computer savvy type. oh vell.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 09:06PM - edited Feb 5, 2012 09:09PM by apple wigs are over rated.. still i'd go to a wig shop for women of color and try on some of the remi wigs..  they are pretty good looking and cheap.  (human hair too from India and indonesia) one can cut a wig to make it suit your face better.  I generally wore baseball caps and silk scarves which i furiously bought at resale joints.  I play publically and will wear a wig then..  ick. I don't go 'out' to often but had wonderful tickets to an opera, to which I went alone.  I got out of my car, and my beautiful wool hat was ripped off my head along with the scarf ... it went flying down the street at 35 miles per hour.. No way could I catch it so i went to the opera bald.  One of the coolest experiments ever.  I got free tickets for the rest of the season.. (bought anonymously) .. people let me cut in line.. praised me for my bravery.. I wouldn't do it again on purpose, but being bald is not all that bad and really only lasts for a while.  facing baldness again in a week or two.. sigh. The American Cancer society offers some for free.. ask at you onc's office for some local links.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 07:17AM apple wrote: i had something kind of mean done to me by a Alzheimer's man.. i was playing the organ and during communion, people walk right behind me.. just inches away.  This guy is Irish.. full of vim and vinegar and used to sing with my choir till he was diagnosed with Alzheimer's.. or maybe that's the excuse his wife give to explain his BEHAVIOR. Anyway, I was wearing a wig (one of two times) and he pulled it off my head while I was playing.  There was a collective gasp... I'm very visible sitting there..  I cried while I kept playing and then forgave him because he was just giggling to himself as he walked away.  one of the ushers brought me my wig and i put it back on.  That was the last time i wore it. (except for a funeral).  I got a lot support from that incidence.... people brought us cakes and lasagnas .. some women came and cleaned my house.. my pastor came over after church to chat. that was the worst i think.  Still I played for him this last year while he sang Danny Boy at a party.. I don't think he remembered.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2009 07:43PM apple wrote: i suppose Jen.. that one becomes 'comfortable' with the thought of a  POSSIBLE shortened lifespan. i guess that's what happened to me.  after the initial cancer diagnosis shock, i just steeled my brain to ignore the fear.. i found it better to be cheerful and optimistic.  writers tell us (at least in the many cancer books that I've read) that a positive attitude is so important.  You've really come a long way in the short months that you've been here.  as you regain your hair and hold and your baby and get on with your life in the coming year and following, I'm sure things would get easier.  there is no magic pill we can take.. all those antianxiety drugs make you tired.. and there is a rebound to normalcy. my little 'i'm going to eat a potato chip at 11 thing' enables me to train my brain to not go there.   something will work for you to decrease your fear.. perhaps just time. glad your baby's still within you and you don't have to deal with an early delivery.
Posts.Title: Venting..... Pure HairSprayMom

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2009 10:30PM - edited Dec 20, 2009 10:39PM by apple I guess i haven't obsessed about statistics because if I read 'mine' i'd know i'd be doomed.   my first six months were pretty dire for me mentally.. and you have only 'been here for a few months.    i know my 'stats' not good.. nothing has changed - i guess I'm just used to the idea of being visited by cancer.  it's really really nice to not walk around with the cloud of gloom hanging over my head.   I imagine you'll get to this point pretty quickly.. you're a source of great encouragement to new women here.     i just decided that it was better for everyone, particularly my family  that i wear a smile rather than be consumed with worry.  Anyway,we'll never figure out how we will end up.. stats are stats and we are individuals.   why not be a survivor?  there is no reason, why you cannot be one of the fortunate, at least for quite a long, long while.  it's the untreated ones who bring the stats down.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 05:44AM - edited Dec 18, 2011 04:35AM by apple Very interesting post and past Mary (I am a Mary too).  My son wants to be a fireman - He says 'how does a doctorate in literature compare with the opportunity to actually save a life'?  that must have been awesome to have been so impactful with your 'patients' .. to get them to where they life can be saved, to actually save them. I remember when i had my major seizure.  it was quite a doozy and there was a woman in the ambulance who kept asking me questions without a smile on her face.. She was focused, demanding and relentless in her quest to keep me conscious.  She asked me my name, She asked me what year it was.. She asked me the names of my children.. I struggled to answer correctly.. She asked me who the 23rd president of the United States was.. I remember sitting up and saying .. the 23rd?  the 23rd?  who would know that except some bitch of a paramedic?"  She then laughed. .. I laughed too.. I can't believe I was so rude. (it's Benjamin Harrison btw.. the least known president in the history of the US).  I have thought a lot about her.. what it must be like to work in the middle of a nite in a mini hospital, flying down the streets with the sirens blaring, the adrenaline, the triumphs and loss.  I have suggested to my son that he investigate being a paramedic.. but he has fire on his mind and is into body building, strength, etc., and has said no thanks. I'm quite impressed with your choice of a master's thesis.  You've had a life filled with a broad scope of experience.  I knew a family who had come from Vietnam... I cooked with the women.. They were actually royalty of a sort, but had plenty of awful stories of death, unfairness and dying. I certainly have had my fair share of family tragedy (3 of my siblings have cancer) 3 of my inlaws have died of cancer,  I have a brain damaged brother, a brother that committed suicide after schizophrenia and a Down's syndrome brother in law.  Life really is unfair for some.. they just don't have the chance to be comfortable and happy and that just rankles me something awful (falling into old Kansas vernacular). You'll most likely live well beyond 5 years.  After being here for a while, it seems so many, even with fiercely oppressive mets are 'doing well' and enjoying life in whatever manner they can grasp. For me, bringing happiness and help into other people's lives has been the way I've been able to be happy... music volunteering etc.  You seem so competent tho.. I can imagine a 'happiness clinic' for the challenged run by you... or something like that.. maybe a visiting visitor (a fairy of happiness (like Mary Poppins) who has a list of those needing cheer... funded by someone like Ellen DeGeneris.. she certainly seems the generous sort).  Want me to write her for ya?  We could all sign our names. I am soooo fortunate to have had my 3 kids and I'm sorry you don't have that opportunity.. However,  a nice little doggie sure would be fun to have around.. to train, to cuddle with and walk.  Maybe you have a dog... anyway, just a pet for companionship and motivation could bring a little happiness. I sure wish you the best.  That was a very important post to read for me.  I am in the midst of quitting my long term accompanist job.  I started my group, directed them. grew them, played for them.. It's a volunteer job - I make my music money elsewhere, but the cost of my meds means i really need to use my Sundays wisely.... I could be makeing 200 bucks rather than nothing and have a LOT more time for other projects.. it's really a no brainer but so hard for me to leave my friends and the certain joy I get from making great church music.  I tried to quit in November, have turned down 2 job offers (I had sent out resumes) but agreed to stay till Christmas.  I hired my awesome director.. and the church pays her.. (kind of grossly unfair, but hay).. She was a seargent in the military, has a doctorate in choral conducting and is a 6 foot, amazon type, Northern European, blond beauty.. (think Darryl Hannah at age 55)..   she is a commandant.. heh... (i certainly don't mean heil)  and has become sort of something like a best friend, altho being friendly is really not part of her persona. good luck Mary. chin up.  maybe your life will be different as it goes on, .... you can still be happy.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 08:39AM apple wrote: YOU  are in control.  There is nothing wrong with saying you need a little time to check with your breast cancer sisters and do a little research. That said.. I think there really are very few surgeons who schedule a surgery to 'make some money'.  I would put great stock in his or her opinion.    Depending on your grade and stage..., surgery does or does not make sense.  If there are 'complications', I do not like the idea of lopping off a breast in pieces.  My tumor was rather large, and there was little debate over whether a mastectomy should or not be performed.. my surgeon looked at me and said 'a mastectomy definitely.. he was very forthright tho and comforting.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 12:11PM - edited Apr 15, 2012 09:09PM by apple so i took an ativan early this afternoon. after an exhausting week.. I'd love to sleep all afternoon and go to bed early.. catch up on some rest. I found a BIG plus.. i can eat!  the thought of even swallowing  turns my stomach.. I've lost 13 pounds in just 3 weeks and i have an onc. visit tomorrow.  So i sat on the sofa.. my son works at a bbq joint and brought me some ribs.. i rarely eat those, but ate them all then a huge bowl of Greek yogurt with very intense raspberry jam i made last year and froze.. yes froze.  absolutely delish... I am thinking of having some toast with butter, or half and avacado with salt.    I could eat toast with butter and avacado.. that would be a pound i bet, all in all.  I still am not skinny but don't even want to go there. every day lately it takes me an hour to eat a small bowl of cheerios.. i drink veggie and fruit juices, almond milk, a couple bites of dinner when people are watching and that's it.  and a beer for the extra 100 calories LOL. i should write a poem about eating on ativan i could eat fish in a can, on a divan i could eat eggs in a pan, perhaps some bran, i could eat fish from the Sea of Japan all in the plan because of ativan.   i could do this once a week and get some rest at the same time.. it's a win peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 10:23PM - edited Feb 21, 2009 07:18AM by apple Ann  Thank you for your post.  Very helpful for me. June i think you will be fine.. i work with a flautist.   surgery will not make your ribcage or lung capacity smaller and you will be able to lift your arms just fine.  you might have a rough year.... but you'll get thru it...   i would certainly plan on continuing to play professionally.  music has been an absolute godsend to me.. a very positive force.  I have continued to improve at the same rate and I haven't missed a single note as a working pianist, except for immediately after my surgery.  Chemo didn't affect my playing altho sometimes i felt a bit poorly. I am also a springboard diver and coach.  Diving requires that the arms be fully extended above the head with flexibility past the vertical.  I only had one side done and have diligently concentrated on physical therapy.  It took me about 6 months for me to be able to stretch my arms past my head.  I am very pleased with my 'scar' and did not have reconstructive surgery.  I have resumed diving and plan to compete again.  (Masters).

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 08:50PM - edited Mar 23, 2009 08:55PM by apple good luck Deb.. you are probably pretty close to the end of your neuropathy issues. (i'm hoping for you). i would not be a bit surprised if i do lose at least a few by the time I'm done.. oh yeah - keep your nails VERY short. (off to lubricate mine before i retire). one thing i do if my fingertips get injured is wrap them with strips of coban (an excellent stretchy bandage).. you can make little fingertip covers that way.  you could probably ask a chemonurse to give you a sample of the end of the rolls which they throw away.  (it comes in many colors).  i can play with my fingertips totally bandaged  - they a real functional.. the tips kind of come off because they don't adhere to the skin, but you just put them back on.  i start with a strip vertically,  about 1/2 inch down from the top of the finger, them make a bend at the top and wrap and stretch about a 3 inch by 1/2 inch strip.. it will self adhere.  i'm sure that is clear as mud.  i will take a picture when i find my camera which is probably lost in mr. apple's work truck.
Posts.Title: Finger/fingernail problems? How common? Texas357 Texas357

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 07:27AM - edited Mar 24, 2009 07:31AM by apple evidence?  who can tell?  in other countries they are in common use.  i go in Thursday and will make my own cold ice bags to hold  (i cannot be too safe or too sorry).  I'll ask my onc if she knows of any published studies.  I certainly feel a bit of compromise at the end of my hands and also know that there is little way of telling if what I've done to prevent neuropathy is worthwhile except to rely on strict monitoring.   * i think the idea is that the contriction of blood vessels keeps the chemo drug from reaching and killing the nerve endings on the fingertips.  i know some women successful have worn ice hats to avoid hair loss.  They gave me ice chips to suck on while i was on the red devil to prevent mouth sores.  i still got them and who knows if they would have been worse. i'll tell you if i can stand the icing tho.  i intend to take some ziplocks full of crushed ice and just keep my hands very cold.  i'm not sure if i will be able to do this for long because i get cold easily when inactive.  the pain is worth the gain for me at this point.   *  as to the glutamine.. i can definitely feel relief in the first four hours of glutamine ingestion and feel tingly and sore if i do not take it.. i've kept very close track.   i am not one to take anything extra generally. the pharmacist said that some women notice a definite 'relief' and some don't.  you are supposed to take it in conjuction with B6. i take 10mg of glutamine and a B6 100 mg at the same time but skip the B6 the third time.  I notice if i miss my evening dose that my hands are swollen and the skin is tight in the morning.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 05:37PM - edited Aug 23, 2011 05:40PM by apple i buy this tea at a Chinese store .. Diet tea... or weight loss tea... ballerina tea.  It basically is a laxative.    it loosens you right up.. overnite... but totally controlled.  only use one bag... and you can drink it in two doses 6 or 7 hours apart.  Make sure you drink plenty of water.  I took pain meds today after being off of them for about 4 months.. wonderful relief.  they are 500mg of hydrocodone but work pretty well for me... they are constipating tho, which is why I quit taking them.  They certainly helped me thru day 14 of Xeloda tho. I like the tea because you can just drink a little... and kind of wait and see.  I hope something so simple is your problem. Best of luck - wishing you a good poop.

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 01:23PM - edited Jun 7, 2010 01:24PM by apple i do not look at stats.. shudder.. i just hate reading that type of thing.  i am just going to pretend that i did not read that 20 month thing.  why would stats apply to you (or me) anyway.     you can read what you can do, what you can eat to increase your survival rate.   I firmly believe you should really love your onc.   I like mine just fine but feel that maybe i need to move on.   she always seems surprised when i prance in as if nothing is wrong.  i know that my sister in law was stage 4 for 5 years after fighting stage 3 for 11 years and my friend is still soccer momming 12 years out. perhaps it is naive to ignore statistics... it's just the way i do things.  I only read my doctor's reports recently and actually wish i hadn't.  ... kind of depressing.  it's very challenging.. hard to cheerful and positive when faced with mortality. and best of luck to you.  it's very encouraging to read posts in this forum.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2010 02:22PM - edited Jul 9, 2010 02:32PM by apple i will certainly do some extra praying.. easy when you hang out at church all wkend. I need to pray for MYself.  i discovered another swollen node.. like, right next to my heart and the study/trial nurse called me this afternoon and scheduled an hour to discuss pain management.. Pain?  I found out my sister might have almost bungled this job for me...I know the cantor (Ann) who sings at this church kind of.  She sang at my dad's funeral about 5 years ago and I've heard her sing a LOT.. she's great.   When my mom died, I mentioned that we could have Ann sing for the funeral.. We were undecided because my mom hadn't even died yet.   My sister went ahead and called Ann and asked her to play and gave the songs that she chose. My mom had already chosen songs, a priest and a cantor and left instructions in an envelope.  (that's my mom heh).   I think my sister then called up  Ann (I don't really  know what she said -  but I know she said something super negative... I'll find out later).  and I think she told Ann that I didn't like her singing and had chosen someone else to sing..  Ann sent me an email saying she hoped that there were no hard feelings between us and she was sorry, and that she hoped we could still work together in spite of my feelings.. it's all fishy.   I am really interested to see what she is sorry for.  I'm thinking my sister told her that I had said that I didn't think she was any good or something like that to cover up the fact that she asked her to sing and my family had already gotten someone else.. it's confusing to me presently. nice sis .. huh?  - my sis has ALWAYS been a bit bonkers. peace and love, apple Diagnosis: 5/10/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 4/9 nodes, ER+, HER2+

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 06:25AM - edited Aug 14, 2011 06:27AM by apple I have a pretty honest and direct relationship with my oncologist.  I trust her opinions and she is open minded to natural ways to deal with disease.  She will tell me if anything I question is bonkers and will also tell me when to investigate further.  I do not mince my words and am detached in a way. She treats all patients and 'owns' many stage 4 bc patients.. She cried when I asked her about ones she has lost so I sense that she loves us.   she said.. "losing someone to this disease is my biggest sorrow". It makes me nervous that she is so pleasantly surprised when my results are good.. she really is so excited with good scans. suggesting, that an ongoing 'questioning' relationship is a worthy goal.

Posts.Content: apple wrote: First of all I am soooooooooooo very grateful to have the energy to actually clean and clean i will. I am actually excited about all the products I will be using today.  yay - sometimes I really get into it.  today I will sweep, vacuum, mop and polish before heading down town to 'play the organ'.. heh.  they probably all cause cancer. I like the very fragranced fabulosa.  I make a spray with just a bit, mixed with water (10 parts water, 1 part fabulosa) and spray everything before washing with a hot rag.  i pour it into my boys' smelly laundry (1/4 cup).  it's awesome.. made by Colgate. I like Comet, Bleach, real lemon oil for polishing wood and and orange citrus super cleaner and degreaser  (the best product ever made)  which you can hardly find anymore unless you order it ....and Murphy's oil soap for really making things smell awesome.. and fake Windex (that I make myself with alchohol and water for the mirrors.  My boys are so ridiculously messy.  Thank g-d I own a girl. Posts.Content: apple wrote:  after a smattering of posts, I introduce myself more formally.  I've been reading these forums for a couple months now. My name is Mary Stevermer.  I'm 52.  In May of '08 I was diagnosed.  I found a tumor in my left breast.  It was really quite large.. almost 5 cm.  They scheduled me for immediate chemo.. 4 rounds of the red stuff and 4 rounds of another, whose name escapes me at present.  I breezed thru chemo and heard that I responded remarkably.  I knew my cancer was fairly advanced at the recognized onset and have never asked to see my actual diagnosis.  I should be about IIIc.  After chemo I had a radical modified mastectomy.  I didn't ask about.  My surgeon is great.  He asked me if I wanted to see pictures of what it would look like and I said no.  He was surprised but went along with my wishes.  He came to visit me after the surgery to take a look.  The hospital conveniently had a little makeup mirror in the food tray device.  He took off the bandages and I was a little surprised to the incision that went from the breast bone up into my armpit.  He did a fantastic  job.  .. even with staples it looked excellent,.  I remember shopping the day after my surgery for groceries. I ran into my nurse friend who couldn't believe I was out.  I told her my arms were intact.  anyway, except for the pesky drains, I had no problems.  I am now almost finished with the 30 rounds of radiation.  Recently, my surgeon found that my supraclavicular node was hard -  biopsied it and found that it was cancerous.. and I then found a lymph node in my right armpit the following week.  I suppose I'll be moving on into the stage IV forum.  Tomorrow I have a petscan  - hopefully they will find where the cancer has mestasticized.  I'm nervous but glad that we are aggresively pursuing this demon.. Perhaps later this week I will ask for my formal diagnosis. I'm a working pianist.. I play at church,.. I have a choir/ensemble and have joined forces with a fantastic director..I also teach, play for competitions as an accompanist and also for ballet classes.  I haven't skipped a beat, literally.  I hope I am able to continue to play for a long time.  I have 3 wonderful kids, ages 9, 11, and 14, and a great husband and extended families.  I'm am well supported and generally cheerful.. Here's a pic of me when I was just bald. my hair is returning slowly.. I imagine I will lose it soon again.  Y'all are a great source of inspiration to me.  I am really glad to know you all are here.  I've cried at your stories and danced with your joys. Here's to a New Year. peace and love, apple - ..... Mary Magdalen Dx 4/10/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 4/9 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: a further introduction apple everyminute

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 07:14PM apple wrote: your kind words are very encouraging. it's kind of funny.  I've never worn a wig till recently.  the thought of losing my hair again spurred me on.  I play in public often and it has always been a challenge to coordinate my outfit and scarves and shoes and hat.  I just bought a wig .. a short dark one.  People's reactions have been awesome yet kind of sad.  "We're so happy for you.. you look just beautiful with hair.  We're so glad you're getting better.  you look so pretty etc. etc. etc." The reason I bought a wig was so people wouldn't have to know i was possibly losing my hair again..  I talked with my two cancer doctors and they said if it was mestasticized (do I have that word right?) that I could very probably do chemo again.   I don't know what to say to them yet.  They are really all so kind and loving.  My priest actually cried.  He's young and idealistic and said he was so happy to see me well - when he saw me in the cute wig.  I just said thank you.. what else could I say?

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 07:39PM apple wrote: what i've been doing. as a taxoled pianist i am OCD about hand issues.. i wear gloves constantly.. leather for housework, latex for cleaning w/ water, stretch nylon for practice.   i put emu oil on my fingernails before sleeping - altho i think any deeply penetrating creme would work  (.. i have pets and kids and read that the tee tree oil can be toxic if ingested).  i warm them rice bags (just microwave) if i have cold spells.  i hold them in cold water if they get hot.  i use lots of lotion. i take glutamine (10 mg 3X daily) and B6 2x daily. it helps immensely for 4 - 5 hours.  I notice in the morning my hands are 'swollen' a bit. i take hydrocodone - i've lots of arthritis anyway, taxol aches and it seems to help w/ neuropathy. i notice days 1 - 5 are worst.. if i miss a dose of glutamine i notice w/in hours.  so far so good.. i just have minor issues.   i practice alot - 2 to 3 hours daily and don't think the constant movement affects my nails.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 02:14PM - edited Jan 4, 2009 02:14PM by apple the reason i feel I've moved beyond IIIc is because of the lymph node(s) in my other armpit that have yet to be biopsied but will hopefully show up or not tomorrow. the nodes showed up after my chemo and surgery.  the supraclavicular was always 'hot' and is being radiated during my current treatment.  my oncologist said that I am hormone receptor positive.. and had planned to put me on tomaxafil after radiation.. at least temporarily, till they know that my periods will not start again.  I don't know why I don't care to know.  It's not that I fear the outcome.. I just want to let the doctor's worry about it, do my best thru treatment - learn piano literature, take care of my family and prepare for their future.  I will ask her when I see her..I promise.  I'm surprised that you all know your diagnoses so thoroughly.  My surgeon has plenty of Dr. Downer in his communications with me so it's not like i don't have a clue. I am fortunate to be in a large metro (Kansas City) and I seem to attend a well thought of cancer center.

Posts.Content: apple wrote: in Zoh's angel thread, a suggestion was made by Kathleen1966 that a book be written.. "When I read that Zoh told her daughter that there was a gold thread that attached her always to her young child's heart, it touched me deeply. It made me think of how wonderful it would be to have a book made about this gold thread"  "Let's do it.  I think this is a wonderful idea.  We could have just a few made, or have it published.. the proceeds going to children of breast cancer victims.  a small glowing, loving book with a cover of gold and maybe a special golden heart inside on the first page.  We could send it to the children we know of, who were left motherless. On the day you were born there was suddenly, a piece of gold was in my heart.  I felt it glow and it gave me warmth and love from you.  You grew, and laughed and got bigger,  glowing in the gold that was my love for you and you for me. Though I may not be with you anymore, know that  a thread of pure gold is tied between our hearts that will never be broken. The thread is only visible to me and to you but it will always be there.  With every tear, with every thought of me, that thread will grow stronger, uniting us in a love unequaled to any love on earth.  A love ........ Please do not interpret my own offered words as definitive or in any way an attempt to oversee this project.. just an idea. peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 08:27PM - edited Jan 17, 2009 08:43PM by apple Hi Estepp from Lee's Summit (practically a 40 minute drive)  I'll get to gether with you sometime after the surgery.. nice to know you... I am a pianist organist at a big church(St. Jo's Shawnee) and a St Peregrine's statue is one of the lovely things I got from parishioners... I should be fully cured, I've had so many novenas, Masses and prayers offered up. Lisa, the meningiomas have sprung up since this last May and one is fairly sizeable, appearing to cover the top corner of my forehead.  It's rapid growth and encroachment that shifts the brain makes them think it is not benign tho they mentioned they thought it should be.   the onc and radiologist guess however, that the surgeon can remove it totally.  They said they very rarely see this type of thing.. and it hasn't been biopsied.  the surgeon is working me in this week, so it's all a bit rushed.  After Tuesday, I will know how the mr. brain surgeon will proceed. about the nodes.. they too sprung up during treatment.  they originally planned for me to do a hormonal but will chemo the system instead.  my poor doctors (radiation and oncologist) were really quite upset.. appearing together to discuss my future with me.  kind of chilling, but they are both such dears. thank you so much for the warm welcome.  I'm so glad to there are others who face similar huge challenges.. we still haven't told our kids and I suppose the next few days will be hectic.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 07:49PM - edited May 5, 2009 11:56AM by apple my son, when he was a baby had compression garments (gloves) for burns.. they were only about 2 inches long.. so cute. i washed them daily.. Dawn worked best for me.    That certainly is a good question. as a pianist who plays with gloves occasionally, you might find these good for over-gloves - you could wear them over your gloves in public.  http://www.gallawayb2b.com/Products/Inspection-Gloves they are a stretchy (not too stretchy) nylon... and come in cotton too.  i found that the cotton lose their shape... however, they absorb dirt and oils better and thus are a bit more tactile.. the nylon ones are slippery-er.   i have a typical woman's size hand and i ordered woman's which i wear alone..  you can get a dozen for $6/25.  the nylon ones wash great in the laundry (with bleach even).  the cotton ones shrink.  you could always get a man's size.  i find them pretty easy to work with .. i can type and play the piano while wearing them.  i wear the nylon ones all the time in the winter. you also might try drying your gloves with a paper towel or three  after squeezing them with regular towels..

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 07:21AM - edited Dec 11, 2011 07:26AM by apple Welcome to Xeloda country.. It's been good for me.  Do check out the big Xeloda thread.  We have lots of fun while we complain.  I think the first thing to do is figure out how to take it so it does not cause an upset tummy.  I personally find i can just eat 30 minutes before taking it.  I often eat a bit of breakfast.. take the big X, then eat a bit more..  i have never had any discomfort altho some women do get nauseaus.  I eat whatever i serve for dinner and Cheerios for breakfast.  Altho, the hand and feet issues take a few cycles to surface it is never too late to start slathering on creams (aquaphor rocks, but just about every serious cream does) and wearing inspector gloves (nylon, sold by the dozen for 8 bucks on the internets) to bed to keep your hands nice and soft.  Some people try the fancy schmancy aloe gloves and socks from Kohl's... i am on a budget. so my husband tells me.  best of luck.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2011 09:32AM - edited Dec 12, 2011 09:32AM by apple happy birthday GroovyWilma.. what a great name.  37 is way too young to contemplate the shortness of life.  Here's to you.  May you enjoy 5 decades more of birthdays. to post a pic.. in the top bar of the reply box is a little tree.  you click on the tree and box opens.  It asks for the URL of the preposted pic.. it could be from a place like photobucket or flicker.  It wants the URL.. not the image code.  you then click in the size box.. and the dimensions will automatically appear.  Unless it is way too big.. like ove 600 X 400  it is fine.. just hit the insert button and the pic will automatically appear.  One can reduce the size just be guessing the math.. say, by a 1/3.  For instance 600 X 400 could be 300 X 200.. kind of small at that size but it will work.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 06:26AM - edited Mar 13, 2011 10:25AM by apple I take a big tablespoon or two of molasses if I get leg cramps and a glass of hot water.  My cramps are not often or severe but they will go away immediately. Prepare for a nice  rush, not really sugary.. just nice.  There are many minerals.. it always works for me.  I had bad cramping on Femara.. so much that i kept a bottle in my car. I drink it in hot milk, coffee or water or swig it straight.. pretty delish. from wiki: " The third boiling of the sugar syrup makes blackstrap molasses. The majority of sucrose from the original juice has been crystallized and removed. The calorie content of blackstrap molasses is still mostly from the small remaining sugar content.[2] However, unlike refined sugars, it contains trace amounts of vitamins and significant amounts of several minerals. Blackstrap molasses is a source of calcium, magnesium, potassium, and iron; one tablespoon provides up to 20% of the daily value of each of those nutrients.[3][4] Blackstrap, often sold as a health supplement, is also used in the manufacture of cattle feed and for other industrial uses." Does anyone remember burning magnesium in chemistry (high school) class? edit:  you might not want to swig it on an empty stomach particularly if you are sugar sensitive.
Posts.Title: Muscle pain? TXGigi apple

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 09:21AM - edited Sep 22, 2011 09:25AM by apple I hope posting in this forum helps for you.  There are many kind, caring helpful women (and men) here for each other.  My heart goes out to you.  Even tho I am doing 'well'.... I am so in love with my daughter - age 12 and it breaks my heart that she might lose me well before age 21.  As Agada said, you are stronger than you think.  .. and I agree with the possibility of exploring anti depressants.   Being under pressure is really hard on you... and an antidepressant can make one so much more efficient and able to work.   I'm really sorry you are out of school and not doing the things your friends are doing.. that sucks.  Being with your mom is so important tho.  I don't think I would want my daughter to leave school but then, I don't live in another country.  I find these days with my children very rewarding and wonderful.  They are respectful, helpful and loving, knowing that i may not be with them.  Your mother must appreciate you so much. Be sure to take care of yourself, eating lots of apples and other fruits.  Sometimes a little fruit sugar is just the thing to get one out of the doldrums of depression.  Not eating can be particularly stressful as it affects one's blood sugar levels for some.  I do best myself with a fairly even schedule of eating, work and rest. I am amazed that you are the responsible one.   warm wishes to you and your mother.  Please stay in touch and feel free to pm me.  As to God.. well, let's hope he (she?) gives you strength.  I am religious and non religious.  I was born Catholic and am very involved in the music ministry.. Yet, if I were Jewish or of another religion I would be comfortable.  I think God transcends our categories and is of help in even bad times.   Sending love and prayers and wishes of support from your community.

Posts.Content: apple wrote: in Zoh's angel thread, a suggestion was made by Kathleen1966 that a book be written.. "When I read that Zoh told her daughter that there was a gold thread that attached her always to her young child's heart, it touched me deeply. It made me think of how wonderful it would be to have a book made about this gold thread"  "Let's do it.  I think this is a wonderful idea.  We could have just a few made, or have it published.. the proceeds going to children of breast cancer victims.  a small glowing, loving book with a cover of gold and maybe a special golden heart inside on the first page.  We could send it to the children we know of, who were left motherless. If you'd care to, please write your suggestions and words of comfort and love.  Someone I know, will see this to fruition.  .. will put it all together and create a work of love... little glowing pictures... symbols of love, maybe even a little joke in honor of Zoh.  It could be a big or small project.  I just encourage us to start this. On the day you were born there was suddenly, a piece of gold was in my heart.  I felt it glow and it gave me warmth and love from you.  You grew, and laughed and got bigger,  glowing in the gold that was my love for you and you for me. Though I may not be with you anymore, know that  a thread of pure gold is tied between our hearts that will never be broken. The thread is only visible to me and to you but it will always be there.  With every tear, with every thought of me, that thread will grow stronger, uniting us in a love unequaled to any love on earth.  A love ........ Please do not interpret my own offered words as definitive or in any way an attempt to oversee this project.. just an idea. peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 02:55PM - edited Apr 13, 2010 02:56PM by apple Kristin.. I would investigate this soon.  One website said chest pain occurred in 8 % of patients, but the website was confusing.  It certainly is good to be concerned.  I would not take something to control that pain but would definitely seek the opinion of another doctor if your onc. doesn't take it seriously.  I hope I don't scare you.. but I would pursue this soon. on our website it says: "Some side effects may mean that you're having an allergic reaction to Femara. If you have shortness of breath or chest pain, call your doctor immediately.  http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/hormonal/aromatase_inhibitors/femara.jsp also on a Femara website.. http://www.webmd.com/drugs/drug-4363-Femara+Oral.aspx?drugid=4363&drugname=Femara+Oral it says:  This medication (and cancer) may rarely cause serious problems from blood clots (such as heart attack or stroke). Seek immediate medical attention if you experience: sudden shortness of breath, chest/jaw/left arm pain, confusion, coughing up blood, sudden dizziness/fainting, pain/swelling/warmth in the groin/calf, tingling/weakness/numbness in the arms/legs, slurred speech, weakness on one side of the body, vision changes, sudden/severe headache.

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 03:10AM - edited Aug 11, 2009 03:13AM by apple oh my heart goes out to you.. my dear brother in law was stricken with a pancreatic cancer that prevented his liver from working,  He had just married at the age of 51, and his 2nd child had just been born.  it was my job  to help him make movies for his children when they got older..   He was filmed alone with no other voices in conversation.   (We should have added some music) the 1st tape was easy.. it was memories of his childhood, his school years, the scrapes he got into, information about his parents and grandparents.  He was able to maintain laughter and cheerfulness.   The 2nd was a message  to his daughters.. what he wanted them to become, his hopes for their future... and it was very difficult to film... We spent days, editting, starting over, writing outlines.  We had to stop because he would get emotional and he wouldn't to project peace and happiness.  If I had the opportunity to help someone again I would bow out and suggest hiring a professional who knows how to do such a thing.   since then I have talked with people who have that sort of business.. they record and create memories, legacies.  You may consider doing that.  In spite of the difficulties, those tapes are the treasured favorite possessions of his daughters.  I marvel how they watch them and are able to laugh and that we even had the foresight to include ways to make them laugh. i wish you peace on your journey and pray for you and your family.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 09:32AM - edited Aug 3, 2012 07:17AM by apple this is kind of an awful little story. I was an organist for my choir and church for many years.  The head guitar player founded the group and always wanted her son to play the organ.  Occasionally, he was allowed to.. he was pretty darn bad.  So I was in the hallway one evening and i heard her say to her son.."Don't worry, she'll be dead soon enough'.  I tiptoed the other way and never let them know I heard them talking.  Now her husband and his father  is dying of bladder cancer.  I didn't think to myself 'just you wait - you'll see what it is like someday'.  If there was ever a time for feeling snarky that was it.   i feel really sorry for the dad/husband.. he is in tons of pain and practically totally debilitated... he is delightful, very nice man .  We had an excellent talk the other nite.

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 12:29PM - edited Aug 3, 2012 12:33PM by apple when I first did chemo and lost my hair.. I was wearing this awful wig for the first time.  I played the organ for services and   the church is a circle and everyone can see the organ, right next to the altar, kind of.  Pat, was/is an Irish drunk, a gorgeous sounding tenor who sang in my choir and was getting Alzheimer's.   He had quit singing a couple years before, but we were still friends. He walked by the organ, grabbed my wig and started running.  Everyone gasped and looked at me.   They grabbed Pat and brought the wig back which i put on after the song.   I had to Keep playing.  Never wore the wig again.  I am a scarf gal..  I forgave Pat, because well,  he was just old Pat.  I still like Pat.   My dad died of Alzheimer's.  Oddly, Pat is the uncle or maybe Dad, of Theresa, the woman who made the comment.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 12:14AM - edited Mar 18, 2010 08:36AM by apple i think you should focus on revving up.  the more activity you can do, the more food, protein and calories you can eat.  If you kept a log of your activity and achievements you may notice that you'll gain daily.  I coach diving  and teach piano lessons.  both activities are measure incrementally and one really has to work work work.  One thing I incorporate into my daily activities.. the time passing by ever so quickly,  is isometric exercise.  Any moment of rest I try to use  to train or strengthen  a muscle or muscle group.  I stand on my toes imperceptably at church for instance,  striving striving striving all the time.  I eat for energy, sustenance and strength building.  I rely on nuts personally for much of my caloric needs.  I just love them.  They seem to go thru me well and give me strength and energy. i hope I'm on the right track here.  I don't know much about your history altho a quick look at your recent posts reveals an amazingly thoughtful woman.  Perhaps you need to think more like an athlete would think. here is a great webpage outlining the need to be active, rest and eat well.. http://stronglifts.com/how-to-build-muscle-mass-guide/ Diagnosis: 5/10/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIc, Grade 3, 4/9 nodes, ER+

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 01:29AM - edited Feb 23, 2012 01:33AM by apple I would not want to be saddled with such an important decision.. After all, if your onc. doesn't have an opinion that she is willing to share... eek. that would scare me.  On the other hand, SHE brought it up so maybe she has an opinion but doesn't want to be 'blamed' if it is not helpful. There are so many women here who thoroughly research and are so great in explaining things. you could post your question in other forums.. like the 'chemotherapy forum'.  Personally my uneducated guess would be to go with the words 'curative intent'.. that sounds good... very hopeful.   Even if a complete cure were not achieved, you still could have a very good result.  i.e.  there is a spectrum of result that may or may not include a cure.  To me it is interesting that the onc. proposed this.   chemo only lasts a bit of time and the result could help you last longer... Bone mets are thought to be pretty treatable.

Posts.Content: apple wrote: I lost my friend to breast cancer.. she's been the most awesome soccer mom ever with metastatic IBC for almost 11 years.  My daughter 11, and her son are the same age.  I've been doing so well until i had this seizure .. now i am a bit retarded.. people don't really know that, but I am.  I told my daughter her kids (4 of them) would be ok.. they just might have to hire a housekeeper occasionally.. and my daughter said.. 'We won't need one.. I totally have the laundry covered. so proud of her.. her attitude and practicality.. (actually her laundry skills are rudimentary.. She can sort, and run BIG loads tho.. bless her little heart). I had played a wedding for my friend's sister in law.. a wild woman, who kind of got married thanks to pressure from her family.  She was ok with it... just kind of the drunk type who likes to have fun.. oh well..  She hugged me.   Everyone wore these very tasteful little pink ribbons at the funeral.. .. I usually don't like them, but they looked really nice, and Terri was always doin the pink stuff... running, walking, raising money.  Bless all their hearts.  The funeral was awesome and so was the music (which I always enjoy). She was born and also died on her birthday,  .. my birthday too.  Kind of special in a way.  She was a special gal. peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: apple wrote: I won't even tell you how much I made but most people would be blown away.  this is after volunteering on Sundays for 10 years. o my gosh.. i had the best, busiest, most profitable day..   I won't even tell you how much I made.   a funeral (with an additional generous tip at 10 am,. a wedding (with another Very generous tip) at 1 pm  and a Mass at 4.00 pm.. no tip. the funerals always 'go' well.  the wedding was absolutely awesome  I played with the Frank sisters; Molly, Genevieve and Moira.. here they are on the news..  This video is at least a year old.. their hair is much longer now. http://www.kmbc.com/news/26749295/detail.html The oldest is a bit of prima donna and a little irritating because i had to listen to how she had to share how good she was.. , the middle one is an extraordinary violinst and the youngest plays the most awesome cello (so does the oldest)... all in all they were wonderfully accomplished and professionally behaved.  The oldest is actually a fairly good conductor.. I am not exactly in 'sync' with her, we have different emphasis but we were awesome.. Maybe I can join their group upon occasion.  My Xeloda hands are not soooo bad. What was really nice, is that they wasted no time whatsoever.. boom - go!  I left the Mass, stopped at Costco, put gas in the car, came home and fixed dinner.   i bought some Boulevard pale ale.  20 bottles!.. which should last quite a while who knew smileys could be so expressive? peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2012 07:35AM - edited Jul 19, 2012 07:41AM by apple wow - lots of information Sheila.  hope you two are beginning to thrive.  I love out little doggie  but he has limited capabilities.  he is sweet, alerts us to strangers, wants to outside, wants to go inside but he can't even fetch. He absolutely adores the family tho.  He looks so funny now because we must shave him so closely  (and we are not very good at it) because of all the burrs we grow outside for him.   The beginning of burr season is hilarious.  His coat is usually about 2 or 3 inches long, and he'll come home literally covered with an armor of burrs.  by the time we cut that off he looks pathetic.  He appreciates that we help him tho.. i am his worst enemy.. he sees me coming with a scissors, brush and comb and slinks off.   hoping some real happiness returns to you Sheila.. depression is very hard to deal with.  Today is my be good to people who drive me bats day.  putting them all together on one day seems a little easier.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 03:12PM - edited Jun 17, 2010 03:14PM by apple there are other treatments.  I myself, trust my onc's judgement more than i do my own. she and her team are up on the latest research. it's wonderful that you are even considering this option.  i personally, would go with the onc's suggestion, but you seem to be doing a wonderful job of supporting Olga, and your caution may well be warranted.  i hope that you do not color your decision with the despair of your earlier position and not truly hope for or expect, a longer tomorrow. you never know.. as many prayers that were offered for you, a good outcome may be in the works.  i am still praying. just my opinion - i would discuss with the onc why he thinks this is the way to go.. could you ask for a 2nd opinion. is he independent?  does he consult with other oncologists?

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2011 07:52AM - edited Dec 19, 2011 07:54AM by apple I used the google to research cancer staging and if you go to the top of the index page.. there are links to important cancer info in this site as well as directions to forums, some for stage 1 and 3 gals.  I think staging a complicated affair.  It is important to have an open line of dialogue with your onc.  This forum has given me far more info than my onc. ever did.  so, in answer to your question - staging changes.  It takes a bit of a while to get used to navigating this forum (it is unfortunately so huge).  the favorite topics link is pretty helpful.   The search function works incredibly well. Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 02:52PM apple wrote: I can't take Ativan. .. it makes me super grumpy, drowsy the NEXT day, and generally uncomfortable.. I'd keep a careful journal, consult your onc. and consider a nightly consumption of a natural product that helps you relax.. Chamomile tea really, really is nice,  the heat helps one sink into sleepines..  as is milk for some,  or ginger tea..   some people swear by melatonin or valerian or beer.  I like beer.. ha ha.  Seriously, i find the chamomile tea with honey or sugar quickly puts me in a relaxed stupor.. the sugar really works for me.  Sometimes the act of consuming a relaxant is just as beneficial as a drug. Best of luck  I agree that psychotropics are not the way to go.  they really do a number on your brain.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 09:11AM apple wrote: Hopefully this fear is the worst you'll feel... ever.   I had a total FAIL on my first pet scan after extensive treatment and they scheduled a MRI.  My radiologist called and said "are you sitting down?"  - I was at Costco shopping.  She told me I had to have brain surgery next week, that she had talked to a surgeon, (the best - oh that was reassuring) and I was on the docket for Wednesday.  My nodes outside my breast and on the other side were lit up and I had a couple liver spots.  I had to do the surgery so I could start on Chemo again as soon as possible.  I went to see the brain surgeon late Monday nite, and he told me it was nothing.. just a menangioma... just kind of large.    I had seen a lawyer to update our will, changed bank accounts, gathered pictures for my funeral.  I was so relieved not having to do the surgery.  I did another 18 rounds of weaker taxol (which didn't phase me in the least after the surgery scare)  and appear to be cancer free.  I shaved my head for nothing, as I really didn't lose my hair the 2nd time.  Today I am packing to move to a new place.. vibrant, but with no delusions of a cancer free life.  I kind of am glad I had that initial scare to put things in perspective. My sis just had a baseball sized tumor removed from her liver that was benign.  Her surgeon feared the worst.  He privately told me to prepare myself, that she might not even make it thru surgery. He told me that many tumors were benign but not hers.  I'm glad he was wrong.  So was he. I pray you pass thru this week without too much worry.  You just never know.     good luck daisy.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2011 12:11AM - edited Jul 30, 2011 12:12AM by apple I had severe water retention once.. after downing a V-8 every day for a couple weeks.  my ankles were swollen... I had gained 10 pounds.  I totally eliminated salt from my diet and it went down immediately.. my onc. also offered me a script for a diuretic but  I never filled it.  I read online that cranberry juice was quite excellent (with no salt on anything)  in ridding the body of extra water.  i drank that too.  I think water retention is a side effect of taxol.. obviously you / she has contacted the oncologist.  if it lasts another day or so, you definitely want to call the oncologist again, because that swelling can be bad for your heart to handle.. Best of luck mom

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 07:27AM apple wrote: blowjobs absolutely totally make me puke for hours. no can do.. and i did promise to do one if my husband paid for my piano.. one of my worst memories ever. now that that is out of the way... cancer kicker.. i really feel for you.  I have been married 18 years.  I never wanted to be married, was not ever looking for husband... went out on a first date with him in '84 after constant urging from my own brother who worked for him.. and then finally married him in '93.  I have never had a sex drive, most likely never will.. i just am asexual.  I am very happily married, dutifully perform my conjugal duties every other day.!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  sigh.., have 3 absolutely wonderful children and love my life.  I have no interest in sex what soever.. I never get horny.  I do love the warmth of my husband and would do anything for him and love him deeply tho.  I wish we could hire a concubine for my husband.. but he loves me deeply and could never even entertain the thought.. i would be so fine with the idea. I have found a few things.. there is a perfect amount of time between sex nites that lets him come rather quickly without going on forever..   I find if I get him horny for a few hours ahead of time he comes quicker.  I apologize for doing the sex duty thing.. i just don't have it in me to pretend to be the sex kitten.. we talk frankly and he understands and is grateful for what i do do for him.. (have sex at all). Do read the thread 'The solution to painful intercourse!!!!!!   right here in this forum.  Do feel free to further discuss.  Men think totally differently than we do... a frank discussion before you put on the wig and try to be what your husband wants may be in order.  I wouldn't be mad at him for just being a man.. believe me.. they never change, but seeing things from your perspective may help him.  I remember sitting down with my husband and telling i simply couldn't have sex daily.. it was stupid.. I am 55.  you think that sort of thing would kind of start dissipating. i sincerely wish you a resolution to your problem and send you big hugs.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 09:07AM - edited Aug 23, 2011 09:08AM by apple well, what's done is done.  Just ask them to respect your decisions on when to let the info out.  Some patients can carry on without hair loss, weight loss, whatever and you may be one of them.  I told my kids before dinner.  My oldest son teared up, my 2nd son went outside and threw up, my daughter looked at me and said "you better be wearing a hat or cut your hair.. we don't want it all around the house when it falls out !"  She was 8 at the time.  (So grateful for my little housekeeper).  I told my husband in prediagnosis times.  He was very collected and calm with the information.  He is fortunately closemouthed.  Once the word gets out... it's out.  I have 7 inlaw siblings and 8 immediate siblings.. It was emailed and facebooked immediately.  I was inundated with donations for house cleanings, casseroles and casseroles and cards..  My own mom was so cool with the information.  She calmly said she was sorry and carried on without undue sorrow.  I am prominent in my church community as THE musician and me dear pastor announced it from the pulpit!  egads.. I was sooo embarrassed. I am a pretty private person and was somewhat assaulted with the onslaught of sympathy but having been taught to be gracious, I was.  I have been blessed with great support. Thank you mom.

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2010 09:25PM - edited Aug 28, 2010 09:32PM by apple I've lost my hair twice.  Since, tho it has grown back.  I've tried Femara and and now Faslodex/Lanitinib.  I don't think it's working and will probably do chemo again (SOON).  It is so nice to have hair.  I never wore a wig the last two times, but i stopped at a wig shop for women of color.  There are so many more choices.  They have REMI (?) wigs made of real Indian hair.. it's is dark, sleek and shiny.. mostly straight.  It's supposed to be hard to take care of, but hay.  They also have SOOO many selections, most priced between 14 and 50 dollars.  I've gotten used to very short hair and this store had some really good looking very short wigs... mostly real hair.    the woman behind the counter.. "chil.. you need to get you a wig cap."  you can bleach and dye the humanhair wigs.. she gave me an old one to experiment with.. I used peroxide.  REMI hair is gorgeous, not like mine, but very real looking.  i added streaks, and painted on degrees of lightness using both a paper towel (bounty) and a toothbrush.  kind of cool.  this link has some of the same styles.  (the roots will never show  because they don't grow). http://africanamericanwigs.net/shortstyles.aspx I also discovered WET AND WILD eyebrow kits. They are no longer available in store where i live, but at 3.99, I'm going to order a lifetime supply.  each kit lasts about 6 months.  http://www.nonpareilboutique.com/makeup--eyes--eyebrow-enhancers--wet-n-wild-ultimate-brow-kit.htmlt here are all sorts of ways to apply the eyebrow and it stays on, looks totally real as if you had hairs. I have both kits and make a blending of the colors.  They are kind of dark and take a bit of experimentation.  Unless i scrub the eyebrows stay on. I have hair now.. i feel the same, but it is so nice to appear healthy.  I really am bothered by the sympathy i see on people's faces.  eyebrows REALLY help one look normal and this next time I'm going to wear a wig in public.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 04:50PM - edited Feb 2, 2012 04:53PM by apple i am one who is quite comfortable working from home.  I have a piano, computer, organ, and art supplies.. plenty to keep me busy, earning a bit of money and happy.  I do take a daily nap now. can't wait.  In fact i get up at five so i can justify a rest in the early afternoon before the kids get home from school. i cook nightly, shop as little as possible, (not one to impulse or browse), do several loads of laundry and clean the house (not thoroughly.. just enough to make it look pretty darn nice). after dinner i am usually about wiped out, so i beg the kids to do the dishes and do them if they don't ... then i lie down yet again and read or watch tv. pretty slothful compared to the former me who use to bike 200 miles a week, chef all day, coach diving and practice piano hours and hours. go go go ... that was me.. now i sit sit sit or stay, stay, stay. i am like a dog

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2011 06:55AM apple wrote: first of all many of us metsters live long and have good quality of life on our stage4meds.. could be you too, so don't be assuming you will be up and leaving them/ i have found the most important thing for me is getting rest.  I need at least an hour more a day.. If i get that nap in I am fine for working hard the rest of the day.. I like my house to be clean too (especially with young younsters).. so if people offer you support, or you can afford it, hire a weekly or bi weekly housecleaner, and schedule more sleep time... you want to be sweet and share happiness with your kids.. I think that is the best thing you can give them (after applesauce). There are so many helpful diet, and exercise threads to read here.  Come on down to the stage 4 forum.   It's about 1/2 way down the 'forum Index tab page'.  UNFORTUNATELY , so many of the women there are in their 30s.. it about kills me.  I am 55.  If anxiety overwhelms you consider an antidepressant.  I love my oncologist and it think it is important to be able to establish a close relationship with a good one.. so if you have a bad one, find another. eat well, drink lots of water and have fun with your kiddies. My heart goes out to you.  big hugs.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 10:40PM - edited Feb 18, 2009 10:44PM by apple first of all my hair is growing back.. it is now very dark and very curly. it was kind of sandy and straight before.  i had my first round of chemo from May to Sep. of 08.  .. i let my kids cut my hair.  a little here, a little there.  we did that for a few weeks then i went to my hairdresser and got a darling boy cut.. i loved it.  i thought i was losing my hair so i let my kids give me a mohawk.. which lasted a day then i buzzed it.  it took almost a couple months for it too fall out, even tho i did the dreaded red devil. a few photos of the progressions to bald. before:   the buzz    the boycut   bald  the pink look

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2009 08:25AM - edited Mar 18, 2009 08:28AM by apple i receive excellent feedback when i go out bald.. i usually wear a scarf as a headband to add a touch of femininity -- much needed since i kind of swagger as i bound thru my errands. one of the most profound encounters was with a 15 year old girl.. she said 'you have the most beautiful eyes - my mom had beautiful eyes.". i hugged her and she cried for about 10 minutes.  we were in a grocery line and we had to go and sit on a bench.  i wanted to take her home with me she seemed so lost, so very sad.  i really wish i had tried to stay in touch with her. this disease touches so many. it is good for people to know we exist and are fighting.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 03:18AM - edited Feb 20, 2009 03:28AM by apple a little anecdote.  Several years ago, one of the 2nd grade teachers at our gradeschool was diagnosed with breast cancer.  (we're good friends now).  She had a double mastectomy, chemo and radiation.  She took a month off during the worst of her chemo.  When she returned to school, wearing wigs and baseball caps the girls had a Locks of Love fundraiser and many of them bobbed their hair.  The 2nd grade boys decided to shave their heads and then all the boys (almost 250 of them) in the whole school shaved their heads on a couple following Saturdays.   I'll have to hunt down a photo of them and the article that was subsequently published in our local paper. it was soooooooo cool.  Little did i dream that i'd lose my hair one day. Melissa now has blond hair to her shoulders, and is doing well. We live very close to the school.. about a block away.  Sometimes I hear them pray for me  and others over the loud speaker in their morning prayers "We'd like to pray for Mrs. N----- -, (Melissa), Mary  S-----------,  (me) Gene and Klara's mother, Giovanna M-------, Mikey and Patrick's mother, and Donna H---------, Michelle and Anna's mother." ....  we all have breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2011 02:19PM - edited Apr 22, 2011 02:21PM by apple i planted some beet seeds yesterday.  I do love beet greens and I'm going to try to love the little red beets as I thin them.  another day, a new attitude.  I'm sorry I've been knocking those beets.  I am the oldest of 9 kids, and my mom's idea of a vegetable was one of those tiny cans of beets (about 8 ounces) for the 9 of us.  I could hardly eat my 7 little cubes... gagging as I tried to swallow them without tasting them with my milk as a kid. Fortunately, I am openminded and do serve them to my family... growing them and having cans.  I eat them too, but not with pleasure. i pretty much love all vegetables and really like celery, sauteed with potatoes and garlic in olive oil... letting everything get nice and crunchy brown before stirring. I parboil the potatoe slices first to use less oil.

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 09:33PM apple wrote: definitely baking soda for brushing and biotene products.  I found bits of avocado during the day extraordinarily soothing.. it didn't gunk up my teeth..   there is a prescription of 'magic mouthwash you can get from your doctor (and you can actually make it yourself.  I swished with that (a much smaller amount than prescribed, many times a day.)  it numbed my mouth, and allowed me to brush thoroughly.  I found it cheaper just to have a prescription but have copied a recipe below.. there are many on the internet if you do the google. -------------------------------------- I work for CVS/Pharmacy and we make magic mouth wash all the time. our blend is equal parts of four products Pink Liquid Benadryl Liquid Maalox or Mylanta Nystatin Liquid(RX only antifungal product) Viscous Lidocaine 2 %(RX only numbing product) sometimes this mixture varies depending on the doctor that requests it, but this is the basic run of the mill reciepe sometimes doctors choose to use different antifungal or different pain products, and sometimes they like a different antihystimine b/c people have a problem with the benadryl, but mostly this is what our patients get if the doctor orders MMW i would guess the doctor calls it "pink magic mouthwash" b/c the benadryl is pink, and sometimes the Nystatin is pink as well, but sometimes its yellow. normally the whole mixture is a chalky pink color. but this is a very good product, trusted and easy, simple works wonders for young children with thrush, people with cold sores, kanker sores, cancer patients with chemo burns its just a good product. if you cant get to a doctor for the RX version. you can use these over the counter products: Childrens OTC Liquid Benadryl Childrens OTC Liquid Motrin Childrens OTC Liquid Pepto or Childrens Kaopepkate(i hope i spelled that one correctly) just use equal parts of each, mix it up in a bottle, you can swab it on the mouth or let the child swish and ITS SAFE TO SWALLOW how much more great can you get plus it will taste good too i really hope this helps you Source(s): 2nd year nursing student, been a phamarcy technician for 3 1/2 years with CVS/Pharmacy. i also use this product myself for kanker sores in my own mouth.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 06:47AM - edited Jan 29, 2012 06:49AM by apple you are a nice son.   it's so nice that you think of your mom. I am often surprised that my kids have no idea how the housework gets done.. i guess they think everything somehow magically goes back into place, clean, polished and orderly.  My kids are learning (i bribe them by giving them dollars) that putting away stuff really helps mom.  I guess I suggest  when you are visiting, to just straighten things up, sweep, do the dishes while you visit. .. just a few little things. Treatments after a while are  fatigue-ing and it is hard to keep up with all the work that maintaining a living space entails. Offer to take her to lunch.. establish a way to communicate daily.. just a few words, tell her you love her every time you leave.  If you can get pass the 'taboo', offer to rub her feet.. I tell you, nothing feels so good to me, altho my sons are absolutely horrified by the idea.  Bring her little things.. a rose, a sandwich, a bit of soup.. things like that,   Ask her if she needs anything from the store.  Altho I am still working and am really not impacted physically too much, the last thing i want to do, is go shopping in the cold weather.  Make sure she has a comfy place to rest.. a reading light, super soft blankies and nice pillow.. maybe near a tv. Like pq2 wrote.. the last thing I want is for my kids (ages 12 - 17) to give up anything in their lives.. I want them to be happy and do the things they are supposed to be doing as if their mom were not sick.  . I try my hardest to teach them how to be happy and to steel themselves for their upcoming grief. Best of luck to you.  Feel free to participate here.  Your mother herself could enjoy this forum.  There are many women from many different backgrounds and of different ages.  Does she live alone? Chances are good that treatments will work well, and she could live for many more years.  I used to think I'd be dead in a year, but years later, I'm still here and quite functional.

I am still pretty productive... my first hours are great.. i do the business things betw/ 5 and 7, while my coffee brews and I start the laundry.. I clean and do the housework thing all morning.. sometimes, most of the time i teach at 10... i try to get my errands done early so i can enjoy that nap. you do not have to endure the headaches.. i take a hydrocodone pill regularly and have virtually no pain..  the oncs can prescribe a stronger one.. i am on a fairly low dose that I take regularly .  it really really helps.

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2008 03:48PM - edited Dec 18, 2008 03:49PM by apple i'm a pianist with cold hands and have yearly struggled with inflexibility and iciness (i  greatly fear lymphedema btw). here are a few of the things i do.. ..wear silk underwear or other long underwear .. you used to be able to buy silk hand underliners for about 3 $ on the net.  (appealing to outdoor workers and motorcyclers).. my husband's extra large ones were HUGE! ..i wear  socks on my hands at nite ..i make a hand warming bag out of raw rice (or corn) in a sturdy sock which i tie or rubber band at the 'ankle'.. i microwave that for 60 to 90 seconds.  it stays warm for up to 20 minutes.  ..i've boiled round stones in water and carried them outside my gloves on the way to jobs ..keeping one's torso warm (i wear wool scarves under my overshirt) greatly helps the extremities.

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 08:33AM - edited Apr 28, 2012 08:37AM by apple she is sarcastic, insensitive and frustrated.  However this sentence does have an answer... ' "More importantly, I wondered if we could ever draw a line, where we say enough is enough, where we say you do not get a second chance at life so that you can just kill yourself in the end, where we say there comes a point when heroic measures cannot cure how people want to live their lives." Livers, organs for transplant and blood are not readily available resources, they are donated.  Medical expenses are not automatically paid by the money tree.  I would like to think that they would be wisely managed and in the end there must be some way of doling them out..  My triathalon BIL who died of pancreatic liver cancer was way down on the donation list.. higher up were those drinkers and those who destroyed their own livers.     I think tho, if i were an organ director I would consider the longevity of the donated organ as a factor in my decision.  I would hate to see a precious liver only last another 3 years.    I see where she is coming from. I am a former smoker and remember running into a newly graduated md in the emergency room.  He was so quick to suggest that I had asthma or COPD during a visit.. i was in there for nothing related to breathing.  in fact, i think i had taken my son in for an ankle injury and had laughed when he asked my  then, 12 year old if he smoked.. and I volunteered that i didn't start smoking till i was 21.    he was such a newby.  i do not forgive her arrogance.  there is a way to discuss issues without judgement.. but also realize she was sharing frustrations with her peers who probably too shared her exasperation with  fixing something that didn't need to be broken in the first place. I don't really care to share the insurance pool i share with the nonresponsible but i do... and that's ok.  We're all human. The comments above have nothing to do with the causes of cancer and I'm sorry if they imply anything controversial.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2010 05:37PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:14AM by apple i've been thru hospice four times with dying parents.  Three of the times were wonderful, and one outfit was just totally innappropriate.  I do hope you find a good match. At the end of life, if this is what it is, I found that asking the parent what THEY wanted was important.  Surprisingly all of them wanted special things that we never thought of.  My dad wanted to visit with a colleague from the 60s, my mom had a funeral file with EVERYTHING outlined.. the songs, the readings, the presider, her dress.  (we vetoed her dress by the way... it had really deteriorated and she was much smaller.  my mother in law wanted perfume that she had always wanted.  Simple things to give them really.  A funny story.. my dad had been in a near coma for about 3 days.  I was holding his hands and telling him how much he meant to me.  He hadn't spoken for about a week.  Suddenly he opened his eyes and asked 'Do you have a car?"... I said yes and he said 'Why don't you drive it home!"  He had Alzheimers. .. very difficult he was, but I still loved him.  I don't know that now is the time for levity, but dying is very much a part of each of our lives and happy death  after a happy and fulfilling life is the most we can hope for. May peace be with you as you go through this sad time.    *still praying for a miracle"
