Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 09:57PM - edited Aug 8, 2011 10:02PM by apple personally Kazza.. at stage III I think you're playing with fire,....... abandoning what modern meds can do for you.. that said I firmly believe that a proactive - hi nutrient diet is one of your best defenses (in combo with the weapons you arm yourself with).   If you watch 'the natural shows' and read current literature you may find (as I have) that the proponents of these ways address weight, wellness, diabetes, heart disease.... but kind of avoid the cancer issue.  They may allude to them but tend to avoid talking about it.. unless saying one can avoid cancer.. and I fully believe diet and supplementation can help.  That said, a 9 cm tumor is really really really large.. If it grew rapidly or slowly is beside the point that it may have very likely contributed to other cancer cells proliferating... particularly since you mentioned the Paget's disease.    I myself am stage IV.. I certainly don't think from any fault of my own... my diet and lifestyle were great.  Do visit the alternative thread.. There is a whole section of this forum dedicated to those who eschew modern medicine totally and 'go natural or altenative'.  It is one thing to be proud of one's choices and another to 'claim victory' too soon.  I don't see anything wrong in extending a kind invitation to the alternative theads. Joy - isn't that a bit too much information .. to assume that an innocent question will me bet with a 'fight'.   anyway, if there is going to be one.. maybe it could be in the proper natural therapies area.  One doesn't usually see the post after post after post after post link thingy in this area.  .. and that's good.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 07:15AM - edited Feb 1, 2011 08:35AM by apple it's an absolutely lovely idea. I'm sorry if you feel like you are intruding. I think one the reasons for the isolation of us stage 4 gals is that our plight seems hopeless for those who face less advanced disease.  I know for myself, I am reluctant to offer anyone hope because I am an example of one without 'hope'.  Still my life is my own and very enjoyable and fulfilling at this point.   We face issues the early stage gals dream of and fear, and it is best to face the future with confidence and courage. When I was first diagnosed in '08, I received about 50 cards.  They really helped.  Now I am so used to my situation.  I receive cards and look at them with wonder.. 'Why would Betty (age 90) send me yet another card?"  She is the only one that does wish me well tho, and she holds a special place in my heart for her thoughtfulness. One thing I would suggest is to perhaps focus on the later stage gals who face major issues.  Sometimes one needs a card shower.  I get the idea that you'd like to pair up gals with gals.  That is nice too.  It is very thoughtful of you.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 07:29AM - edited Mar 1, 2012 07:31AM by apple one of the best things about having a medical condition is the exposure to new words.  I love how they are made and how English is so very incorporative of influences.  My dad taught Latin and Greek thruout his life and he would make us say "pass the peas" in Latin.  I remember having a huge argument with him because I couldn't remember how to say it so I said, I absolutely do not want any peas... i hate them.. "nolo paganus. EGO contemno lemma.. something like that, and I don't really remember. .  I got to skip the dreaded peas that nite.  I was the oldest of 9 kids and my mom would open a can, put them in a pot and cook them for 20 minutes till they were grey... she'd give each of us a tiny spoonful.  We stuck them in our mouthes and swallowed them with milk.  ick. English incorporates words form the silk road, the pacific,  I find it fascinating.  I've made a little money as a English major.. writing for patent lawyers and grain publications.. I hated it.  Anyway, conspicuity is a wonderful word but we certainly don't want to hear it.  You should have seen what they said about my brain mets.. I'm not even going to share. Wishing the best for you Ann.... just trying to take your mind off your troubles

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 09:07AM - edited Mar 17, 2011 09:40AM by apple WE buy everything used.. except underwear, shoes and computers (and even those might be refurbished).  We have always been incredibly stingy with our disposable income.. our poor kids are so jealous of those who get to travel for spring breaks and buy new clothes.  they are happy tho. I buy in bulk and stock up when things are on sale.  We keep our heat ridiculously low and blankets are strewn around the house.  We wear long underwear and 2 - 3 shirts or sweaters.  I am glad warm weather is coming.  mr. apple values every bit of tissue and will never throw used napkins or the like away if he can 'reuse' them.  Every trickle of water is carefully watched. .. our showers our timed, we try to the dishes with the least amount of water, we save the water coming out of the shower (as it warms up) in a pitcher and then use it in the kitchen One of the biggest expenses is utilities and it's also one of the easiest ways to save.  We have found that a slow trickle of hot water in the sink uses the least amount of water to bring it up to temperature.  mr. apple will even save that water and use it in the toilet...   We save our used clothes to use as paper towels and sell our stuff at garage sales.  Our kids try to earn what they can and trade their toys, trying to upgrade with every trade.  We pay bills on the last date possible to keep what meager interest we earn accumulating.  my husband is kind of a nut but he has done very well being such a tightwad.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2012 06:38AM - edited Feb 16, 2012 06:42AM by apple it is devastating to think of our kids.  That said, mine are doing well.  They are so respectful and helpful and loving.. i guess I am blessed.  I remember announcing the cancer news to them about 4 years ago.  My oldest, then 13 just looked at me with tears welling up.. son #2, then 10, went outside and threw up and my dear daughter, 8, put her hands on her hips, looked at me kind of cockeyed and said 'We're going to have to cut your hair get a hat for you!  we don't want you hairs all over the house! "  I about died it was so funny.  I am facing hair loss again and she is kind of excited.. she really likes the idea of wigs and REALLY wants me to get a blond, flowy style. yeah right. but seriously.. i don't know these formative years are special and the thought of being robbed of them is heartbreaking.  They still can be important while we are here.  I'm hoping to last 6 more years which is highly unlikely.. As to coping.. well, I am going to try to get as much fulfillment, influence and enjoyment out of these years as I can.    maybe someone can help you clean your house so you can sit down and play cards or something with your kids.  time is important.  you know, you have to prepare them to cope with suffering.. while it is hard, it's pretty interesting.  Suffering is a part of life and tools to enable kids to cope are very valuable. and btw.. be hopeful!!! you could last many many years, even to see her graduate and give you a grandkid.. you never know.
Posts.Title: Coping as a young mom? rosasmommy klynnz

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 05:14PM - edited Oct 13, 2010 05:15PM by apple best wishes for you and your mama. in the task bar in the reply box is a square with a tree in it.,, next to the smiley face.   Click on that and a box appears.. The top slot asks for an image URL.. that is the address of where the picture is hosted.  If you use photobucket for instance, it is called 'direct link' and the code begins with http.....  copy and paste that into the top slot.  then click on the dimensions box and the dimensions should automatically appear..  you then click on INSERT and it will insert the picture into the reply box,  (where you type your posts).  that's about all you need do.  you can also write a description. This assumes that you have a hosting site that stores your photographs like photobucket   you cannot upload a pic from your drive as far as i know.. hope this helps. peace and love, apple Diagnosis: 5/10/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 4/9 nodes, ER+, HER2+

Posts.Content: apple wrote:  I have this son #2.  He is a massive boy - mostly muscle and bone but plenty of chubby who decided to go out for wrestling.  He never does his homework.  I am always getting these F emails from his teachers, but less and less of them since the season started 4 or 5 weeks ago. All of a sudden his room is NEAT.. books put away, clothes folded, the bed made and I can tell he is trying in school. He had his first tournament yesterday. I couldn't go. but he won 5 of 5.  All he said when he came home is that he did ok and wanted to eat.  Later his coach called and basically said.. "OMG - your son is such a champ.  He doesn't even have wrestling shoes, is pretty fat for a wrestler and not only did he win every match but beat the senior state heavyweight champ in the back room.  I saw it.   The state champ apparently wanted to beat his butt and teach him a lesson. .. but no.  Gene pinned him like he was a butterfly and he's a freshman.. a freshman!!" I have no idea how Gene learned to wrestle.  When he was born, his breast plate stood up, one side over the other.  The doctor said he probably would grow into himself and it would straighten out and probably it was an indication of a large upper body later on.  He is 14 and growing out of his size 14 shoes.  Why do i have to have this friggin cancer.. ? I really really really love my kids.  they are so cool. here he is at World's of Fun in KC.. the best picture I have of his feet. peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: apple wrote: .. i play the organ down at an old church with a long term Italian (and Vietnamese) congregation. i love it.  Anyway the Mass today was said for Mike Lombardo.  I just loved him.. he died about 5 years ago from cancer and I found out about his death just a couple years ago.  I worked with and for him for about 8 years. He was absolutely adorable.. handsome, with a NY Italian accent.  He wasn't very smart but super respectful, kind and well loved.  I used to send him love poems as a joke.  mostly silly, clever, short poems.. like this. Dearest Mike Lombardo i love to watch you walk you slowly rock from side to side kind of like a guy with jock itch. I wrote him a secret poem every week for many years.  I didn't love him really.. just as a friend.  Anyway, he just loved the poems and would read them to us every week.  I never told him the poems were from me.. that they were from a secret admirer was kind of special. I talked with his parents and told him how much I just loved him.. his wonderful character and kind nature.  it was nice.. kind of sad.  he was only 52. peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 09:42AM - edited Jan 28, 2009 10:09AM by apple my daughter is not quite a teenager.  I would be honored if she came to me with her concerns.  Your mom has breasts too.  Altho it is unlikely that your problems are serious, it really is better to check them out.  I really hope you can talk to her.  I adore my girl child.  You'd be surprised at how much moms can handle.  You could also talk to a counselor at school, but I myself, would much rather go to my mom. I have some pretty serious problems now and my mom is 82.  I didn't want to worry her or tell her about my problems, but she was the most comforting and helpful person I've talked to since my diagnosis.  She is there for me, even tho she is aging herself.  I adore her too.

Posts.Title: stiff thumb can it be fixed Viktoria apple

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 08:58PM - edited Jan 23, 2009 09:02PM by apple yes,  osteo.  thank goodness not rheumatoid.  Simple overuse.... i was a gymnast, diver, cyclist.  I am in good shape, but my knees are pretty compromised.  as a pianist I am very aware of my hands.  4 hours of practice will produce swollen knuckles and all sorts of aches and pains.... personally, I've found that the best policy to avoid pain and swelling is to avoid overuse and impact.   Funny, I've been avoiding nsaids and other pain relievers, hoping to save my digestive tract for the far future, which seems much nearer now.  nsaids do reduce swelling and I imagine why it is caused is not of consequence treatment wise.  I haven't discussed this with my doctor as it really isn't an issue now. i really haven't noticed an increase in arthritis, but there is a general increase in my creakiness. severe swelling responds well to alternate warmth and ice-ing.

Posts.Title: bummer apple apple

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 07:21AM - edited Feb 27, 2012 07:26AM by apple I've had to cool it with the IDIOT word for the sake of my kids.  there is nothing as satisying while driving as letting out a 'you friggin idiot" when someone makes a bad move.. but .. well, my kids, at least do what i do and started using the idiot word.  When I was confronted by a life challenging move by a woman who came flying off the highway into my line of traffic, and I dodged her, the cars to my left and then my right as I was coming back into a line of noncollision.. i was very calm and cool.. She waved an apology and I waved back.. I remember this man looking at me with absolutely wide astonished eyes.  I thought I was pretty cool, driving like a racecar driver and not reacting under pressure.  I still say idiot. I absolutely hate it when when people ask me how I am.  I don';t like sympathy.. i usually feel fine.  i hate the heartfelt furrowed brow, and deep tearing eyes of the empathetic.. I don't like sharing medical info.  I don't like gossip.  I kind of left my church community over this.  I couldn't go anywhere without the 20 questions coming at me.  When I made my business cards a couple years back I made a little card that said I'm doing good" I don't talk about my cancer EVER Nicely centered in Green, Bold, Garamond font #18 on a greyish background.. Word got around and  people really didn't bother me for a while.  It didn't last long tho in the long run, and I figured the card was a bit too attention getting because I got a LOT of casseroles.  that was nice.  I generally love people and the positive things they share.. it's just so darn embarrassing being the sick one.  I don't even feel sick.. it's just a pain in the arse... all the appointments and hairloss and stuff like that and I really don't like talking about it with the same ol' same ol' eyebrow raising people who take pride in their empathy and compassion. Down with this sort of thing! (3 stars to anyone who remembers that line)

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 07:56AM apple wrote: you poor thing and your poor kid. .   I suspect he is freaking.. it must be so hard to live with such tension and sorrow. One thing I discuss with my children is 'building character'.. and what they are going to do each and every day to improve.. We openly discuss flaws (laziness or bitchiness for instance) and how embracing the opposite will make them a better person.  I take walks with them which is a good one on one time.. we are moving, and positive and i try not to be judgemental.  My daughter had the brilliant idea that she needed counseling.  She set up a mini psychiatrist office in the living room with a pen and notepad for me.  She laid down on the couch and we had a wonderful talk.  I pretended to be a shrink.. It was very very helpful.  I know an 11 yr. old whose father is dying.  the kid fell in love with my daughter and was threatening suicide.  eek.  I talked with the kid on facebook quite a bit.  It takes so much energy to shape children and you are probably stretched way too thin. my best to you in this time.

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2012 08:15PM apple wrote: I am on my new property and want to plant tons of stuff in the next couple years.  hibiscus, lilacs,  a lot more knockout roses.. they do so excellently here.  I planted six, 1.5 years ago.. they are ready to bloom, and sit predominantly on a hill above the driveway.  I know everyone has them, but i love them because they bloom and bloom and bloom and are totally disease resistant.. Posts.Content: apple wrote: many of you have asked how I am doing.. so I'll conveniently compile an update here.  (thanks for the space stage 4 gals.. and I really do feel stage 4). Here is my original thread on this seizure.. http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topic/767630?page=4#idx_116 I saw the neurosurgeon and here compared MRI slides and CT scans from 2008 and this last month and concluded the meningioma is growing very slowly.. just 2 cms in 2.5 years.. from 25 to 27 cms.. (maybe those are millimeters.. I am math challenged.. bigger than a flat walnut I think).  The concensus seems to be that it would be unwise to remove the meningioma at this time.. so no surgery. My brain is so damaged and my drugs are soooo strong.  I can't drive, everything is different..  Still I can still write and play the piano, and work... I am just soooooooooo loose and sloppy.. my thinking is a bit hallucinatory, not unpleasant and my eyes are a bit whacky.. things aren't exactly flat for instance..  my arms look floppy and fat.  I have never had fat arms. I am really enjoying writing and will compile the anecdotes and essays I've been storing in the computer for my kids, etc. I really have been fascinated by these mental changes and have been posting updates on facebook for friends and family.   My memory works in a different way now.   you can be my friend if you wish on facebook.. I am mary bryde stevermer.  https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=1660381997 My brain is working.. it's just so different.  The anti seizure meds ARE VERY STRONG and I am most interested in tapering to a working, more functional dose.  Prayers for all of you and particularly Yan and Alphons.  peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Title: was i really bald? apple Beverly11

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 03:36PM - edited Jan 11, 2010 03:38PM by apple no problem - they did a scan after my treatment and they found out the my cancer had actually spread during my treatment to the axillary and middle nodes (they also thought i had a brain tumor - but thankfully that turned out to be nothing).  .. or maybe the scan just picked it up and it had been there all along.... so it was onto chemo again..  it's been a long long year or two. mine was already pretty established and very agressive at the onset  - man, it grew so fast once i found it.  .. it's odd, because I had an excellent response or so they say, to my first chemo.. the tumor to nothing... i couldn't even feel it.  my surgeon actually, was very adament about them doing another scan according to his interpretation of the pathology reports.. He was quite old for a working surgeon (with an excellent reputation). i'm really grateful to be at this point of actually having hair.  eek
Posts.Title: was i really bald? apple Beverly11

Posts.Content: apple wrote: sooooooooooo... after my chemo session i stopped at Sam's to pick up some fish for dinner.  i  cane out of the store, went to the car and i am clicking the keyfob to open the door.  Nothing happens.  i click, i click and a little family is watching me.  i figure the battery is out on my automatic door opener so i try it the old fashioned way.. i stick the key into the car and the  alarm goes off.   I know that to make the alarm stop, i need only click the open or lock button on my key fob.  so here i am in the parkinglot, clicking a car that has a blaring horn and i am attracting attention.  i look in the car and it has red seat covers and i think .. wtf?   whoops, no profanity..actually i did form the letters wtf in my head.  They're engrained because i belong to a forum called the  Well Tempered Forum and it is called WTF for short.  i don't actually ever say the word anyway.. it wasn't my car  - my car was across the driving path.  i just looked at everyone and grinned. i waited for security to come out and explained.. they know me, so I didn't have any problems. geez. got a chemobrain moment to share?  peace and love, apple - ..... Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 07:10AM - edited Apr 26, 2011 07:12AM by apple I was really tired yesterday till around 5.. after all the cooking for Easter. I did kind of get it together tho for dinner and cleanup.  I took a long walk with the doggie and I guess I am going to have create my own therapeutic recovery program.  My immediate memory is so toast.  I am on a task and start looking for something.. While looking I forget what I am looking for and simply have to move on to a new and different thing to do.  It's funny and fascinating..I don't remember whose clothes belong to who altho I know my daughter's.  All the guys are about the same size so they;re just going to have to find their clean clothes themselves on the somewhat organized laundry shelves. drugs.. gah! the definite concensus is that the menignioma is not related to the breast cancer... altho they haven't biopsied it.. it has all the signs of benign ness and they said removing it would not help that the inflammation would still be there.  I have followup appointments tho.. so I guess a more specific analysis will emerge.
Posts.Title: a bit of update. apple Hopbird

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 05:49AM - edited May 1, 2011 06:00AM by apple doing better every day..  I am focusing on vigor.  I  could hardly get off the couch when I first came home... I had to lift my legs with my hands,  and I've worked non-stop now for 2 days.. kind of slow, but hay (as they say in Kansas). I am grounded from the car for 6 months at least (probably because these drugs would give me a DUI, and I don't remember that left hand turn lanes are supposed to be obeyed and such).  I live a mile from several areas that are good to shop at.  Definitely not delightfully urban or European, but I think I can find some good socks at Kohl's.  I ordered a pedometer from ebay. and absolutely am LOVING being on foot again, after doing all that driving for the last 20 years.  I love to drive, but ick,, so much stupid gas. got a couple gardens in yesterday with Pedro's and my sons' help. I'm happy and confident that recovery will continue. I live in the best place ever.  a little farm we just rebuilt and moved to this last year,  and  will finish putting in a concorde grape arbor  (so delish) another sun garden, and other things to eat,, like long beans, squashes, berry plants.  it's so exciting.  Too bad I'm going to be joining that invisible choir.   I am just getting an idea of the scope of damage.. WOWZER, OMG and  LOL. (I am finding the shortspeak texting acronyms efficient and fun.. They work really well for me when I can't think of real English words.  - I know they can be irritating tho, and maybe I'll be fazing those abbreviations out as my brain improves.)  My brain is working pretty well, but for instance, the last 2 weeks are a bit of a blur.   I don't remember some things.. I do remember other things tho, like how to play music so I am looking forward to directing my mental recovery with things like practice.  I love that sort of thing.   People are being so nice.. sending food, taking me garage sale=ing and shopping.,  My onc. seems to think I am responding well to Xeloda.. altho I am very interested in trying to determine how Xeloda's methods of attacking cancer may have contributed to this seizure thing. Have a nice day sistahs!  I cry for those in pain and compromise, and pray, think and hope  for you all daily... at least some of these last days.. I might have forgotten a few there in the last couple weeks.  (LOL) peace and love, apple Diagnosis: 5/10/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 4/9 nodes, ER+, HER2+
Posts.Title: a bit of update. apple Hopbird

Posts.Content: apple wrote: many of you have asked how I am doing.. so I'll conveniently compile an update here.  (thanks for the space stage 4 gals.. and I really do feel stage 4). Here is my original thread on this seizure.. http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topic/767630?page=4#idx_116 I saw the neurosurgeon and here compared MRI slides and CT scans from 2008 and this last month and concluded the meningioma is growing very slowly.. just 2 cms in 2.5 years.. from 25 to 27 cms.. (maybe those are millimeters.. I am math challenged.. bigger than a flat walnut I think).  The concensus seems to be that it would be unwise to remove the meningioma at this time.. so no surgery. My brain is so damaged and my drugs are soooo strong.  I can't drive, everything is different..  Still I can still write and play the piano, and work... I am just soooooooooo loose and sloppy.. my thinking is a bit hallucinatory, not unpleasant and my eyes are a bit whacky.. things aren't exactly flat for instance..  my arms look floppy and fat.  I have never had fat arms. I am really enjoying writing and will compile the anecdotes and essays I've been storing in the computer for my kids, etc. I really have been fascinated by these mental changes and have been posting updates on facebook for friends and family.   My memory works in a different way now.   you can be my friend if you wish on facebook.. I am mary bryde stevermer.  https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=1660381997 My brain is working.. it's just so different.  The anti seizure meds ARE VERY STRONG and I am most interested in tapering to a working, more functional dose.  Prayers for all of you and particularly Yan and Alphons.  peace and love, apple - ..... Mary Magdalen Dx 4/10/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 4/9 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Be good stay well apple bobkat

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 09:40AM apple wrote: those girl drugs totally wipe me out.. so mine still work (but are really 3 years old)... a couple ativan and anti depressant.. not really my type of thing, but they sure make you sleepy and pleasant feeling. We've been in SanDiego since early Monday.  2 growing huge boys 17 and 14, mr. apple, and me and the girlchild (12). I got to visit with my old roommates and best friends.. They basically are government / science interface of Scripps.. sooooooooooooooooooooo incredibly special.. and super super interesting.  I've gotten to spend some excellent time with them the air is so incredibly comfortable, cool, dry, warm, no pollens, clouds and sunshine every afternoon.  the kids were genuinely interested in maritime and military things (omg the air craft carrier), We absolutely adored the botanical gardens and tide pools.  so many cool plants... incredible bamboo and tree specimens.  It's been a chore logistically coordinating everyone and their caloric intakes.. (i could eat one bowl of oatmeal, a slice of cheese and a couple apples in a few days and be totally fine).. soooo this morning we are going to go pig out on steak and eggs or something like that and pop on the train and vegetate till early Monday.  I haven't had any steak in years and it sounds pretty good. The train was actually very comfortable and afforded great conversations and card games. .That was my report.  I hope you enjoyed it.  I'll be 'seeing' you soon.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 07:25PM - edited Dec 1, 2011 07:37PM by apple sigh..... so many arguments, so little time. I actually have some time now.  Thank you Chemo! No one wants to do chemo.. no one.. but  am I ever grateful that it has worked for me.. I'd be long gone. As to the disservice... i think those who want to eschew chemo are early stage.  I think most people seriously facing this beast would rarely consider choosing to opt out.   I do cringe every time the subject appears.. For some reason, it really makes me feel bad, mostly because they are so proud to be cancer free.  It always doesn't work that way. So is it a problem..?  Perhaps.  I tend to think so, especially when misinformation is shared.  However, many of the alternative treatments I employ, and they can be helpful.  Eating healthily, exercising, taking some supplements are good to embrace.. Coffee enemas and 100 pills a day pushed by the silicone Barbie, "napalm-grade stupid about cancer*  "Suzanne S. ...  no thanks. As a non-newbie, I just don't engage in that discussion... (except for now).  I do wish the alternative - hate modern medicine gals would be less exuberant in their support of not embracing modern medicine and less enthusiastic about whatever cancer cure makes the news, researched or not. oh well.    There are controversial  threads that have been banned from appearing in the active topics list.  If it is a perceived problem - that could be an option. * hat tip to scienceblogs.com and 'Orac'  a brilliant yet funny, researcher, doctor, and  blogger..   peace.
